trans-unit.source: ACS Performance Guidelines
trans-unit.target: ACS Performance Guidelines

trans-unit.source: ACS Performance Guidelines
trans-unit.target: ACS Performance Guidelines

trans-unit.source: Applies To
trans-unit.target: Applies To

trans-unit.source: Windows Identity Foundation (WIF)
trans-unit.target: Windows Identity Foundation (WIF)

trans-unit.source: Summary
trans-unit.target: Summary

trans-unit.source: This topic outlines key performance guidelines that you should take into account when you develop applications and services that use <token>secondref_acs</token>.
trans-unit.target: This topic outlines key performance guidelines that you should take into account when you develop applications and services that use <token>secondref_acs</token>.

trans-unit.source: In particular the topic provides guidelines regarding token sizes and cryptography and how it affects overall performance.
trans-unit.target: In particular the topic provides guidelines regarding token sizes and cryptography and how it affects overall performance.

trans-unit.source: Overview
trans-unit.target: Overview

trans-unit.source: In general, the key attributes of performance are response time, throughput, and resource utilization.
trans-unit.target: In general, the key attributes of performance are response time, throughput, and resource utilization.

trans-unit.source: For example, if the application has limited resources such as memory, chances are some information will hit the file system which is much slower than in-memory operations – this will affect overall response time.
trans-unit.target: For example, if the application has limited resources such as memory, chances are some information will hit the file system which is much slower than in-memory operations – this will affect overall response time.

trans-unit.source: Here is another example, if the application sends a large amount of data over a network with limited bandwidth, it results in slower than desired response times.
trans-unit.target: Here is another example, if the application sends a large amount of data over a network with limited bandwidth, it results in slower than desired response times.

trans-unit.source: One approach to solve performance issues is to add more resources such as network bandwidth, faster CPU, and more memory.
trans-unit.target: One approach to solve performance issues is to add more resources such as network bandwidth, faster CPU, and more memory.

trans-unit.source: This approach may help although not always.
trans-unit.target: This approach may help although not always.

trans-unit.source: Another approach is to improve code so that it uses fewer resources and exchanges less data.
trans-unit.target: Another approach is to improve code so that it uses fewer resources and exchanges less data.

trans-unit.source: Considering the context of claims aware applications and what’s under developer’s control there are a few key factors related to using <token>secondref_acs</token> that affect performance, namely, tokens and cryptographic operations related to the tokens.
trans-unit.target: Considering the context of claims aware applications and what’s under developer’s control there are a few key factors related to using <token>secondref_acs</token> that affect performance, namely, tokens and cryptographic operations related to the tokens.

trans-unit.source: Objectives
trans-unit.target: Objectives

trans-unit.source: Define the aspects that affect performance in applications that use <token>secondref_acs</token>.
trans-unit.target: Define the aspects that affect performance in applications that use <token>secondref_acs</token>.

trans-unit.source: Provide guidelines how to improve performance for each of the aspects.
trans-unit.target: Provide guidelines how to improve performance for each of the aspects.

trans-unit.source: Tokens Size And Encryption
trans-unit.target: Tokens Size And Encryption

trans-unit.source: Token size and encryption are key factors under the developer’s control that affect performance of applications integrated with <token>secondref_acs</token>.
trans-unit.target: Token size and encryption are key factors under the developer’s control that affect performance of applications integrated with <token>secondref_acs</token>.

trans-unit.source: <legacyBold>Token Size.</legacyBold> Token size affects performance in two ways.
trans-unit.target: <legacyBold>Token Size.</legacyBold> Token size affects performance in two ways.

trans-unit.source: First it directly affects performance related to network bandwidth to some degree.
trans-unit.target: First it directly affects performance related to network bandwidth to some degree.

trans-unit.source: The larger the token the more network bandwidth it will take resulting in slower response overall.
trans-unit.target: The larger the token the more network bandwidth it will take resulting in slower response overall.

trans-unit.source: Second, the larger the token the more CPU cycles required to verify the integrity and extract claims in the token.
trans-unit.target: Second, the larger the token the more CPU cycles required to verify the integrity and extract claims in the token.

trans-unit.source: Token processing includes parsing the token and de-serializing it into binary format so that your code can use it, the processing also includes several cryptography operations such as signature validation, and optionally decryption.
trans-unit.target: Token processing includes parsing the token and de-serializing it into binary format so that your code can use it, the processing also includes several cryptography operations such as signature validation, and optionally decryption.

trans-unit.source: The larger the token the more CPU cycles spent on its processing resulting in higher resource utilization and slower overall response.
trans-unit.target: The larger the token the more CPU cycles spent on its processing resulting in higher resource utilization and slower overall response.

trans-unit.source: Token size depends on several factors: token format, cryptography applied to the token, and the claims in the token.
trans-unit.target: Token size depends on several factors: token format, cryptography applied to the token, and the claims in the token.

trans-unit.source: ACS supports SAML, SWT, and JWT tokens.
trans-unit.target: ACS supports SAML, SWT, and JWT tokens.

trans-unit.source: Generally a SWT or a JWTJWT token is smaller than a SAML token that carries equivalent amount of information.
trans-unit.target: Generally a SWT or a JWTJWT token is smaller than a SAML token that carries equivalent amount of information.

trans-unit.source: For more information read <link xlink:href="5fd7e09f-0c5b-4571-943e-c743ee0bac9d" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">Token Formats Supported in ACS</link>.
trans-unit.target: For more information read <link xlink:href="5fd7e09f-0c5b-4571-943e-c743ee0bac9d" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">Token Formats Supported in ACS</link>.

trans-unit.source: There is caveat though, different token formats are optimized for different protocols and application architectures.
trans-unit.target: There is caveat though, different token formats are optimized for different protocols and application architectures.

trans-unit.source: SWT Tokens are issued over WS-Federation, WS-Trust, and OAuth WRAP or OAuth 2.0 protocols.
trans-unit.target: SWT Tokens are issued over WS-Federation, WS-Trust, and OAuth WRAP or OAuth 2.0 protocols.

trans-unit.source: This means that SWT tokens can be used in Web applications, WCF (SOAP) services, and WCF (REST) services.
trans-unit.target: This means that SWT tokens can be used in Web applications, WCF (SOAP) services, and WCF (REST) services.

trans-unit.source: WIF does not support the SWT token handler.
trans-unit.target: WIF does not support the SWT token handler.

trans-unit.source: SAML Tokens are issued over WS-Trust and WS-Federation protocols.
trans-unit.target: SAML Tokens are issued over WS-Trust and WS-Federation protocols.

trans-unit.source: This means that SAML tokens can be used in Web applications and WCF (SOAP) services.
trans-unit.target: This means that SAML tokens can be used in Web applications and WCF (SOAP) services.

trans-unit.source: WIF supports both SAML 2.0 and SAML 1.1 tokens.
trans-unit.target: WIF supports both SAML 2.0 and SAML 1.1 tokens.

trans-unit.source: Read more about WIF in the following topic <externalLink><linkText>Windows Identity Foundation</linkText><linkUri>http://msdn.microsoft.com/library/ee748484.aspx</linkUri></externalLink>
trans-unit.target: Read more about WIF in the following topic <externalLink><linkText>Windows Identity Foundation</linkText><linkUri>http://msdn.microsoft.com/library/ee748484.aspx</linkUri></externalLink>

trans-unit.source: JWT Tokens are issued over WS-Federation, WS-Trust, and OAuth 2.0 protocols.
trans-unit.target: JWT Tokens are issued over WS-Federation, WS-Trust, and OAuth 2.0 protocols.

trans-unit.source: This means that SWT tokens can be used in Web applications, WCF (SOAP) services, and WCF (REST) services.
trans-unit.target: This means that SWT tokens can be used in Web applications, WCF (SOAP) services, and WCF (REST) services.

trans-unit.source: One factor that contributes most to the token size is the claims contained in the token.
trans-unit.target: One factor that contributes most to the token size is the claims contained in the token.

trans-unit.source: The more claims the token carries the larger its size.
trans-unit.target: The more claims the token carries the larger its size.

trans-unit.source: In most cases claims that come with the token are under developer’s control.
trans-unit.target: In most cases claims that come with the token are under developer’s control.

trans-unit.source: The claims used by an application are added, removed, or changed by the Security Token Service (STS) such as AD FS or <token>secondref_acs</token>.
trans-unit.target: The claims used by an application are added, removed, or changed by the Security Token Service (STS) such as AD FS or <token>secondref_acs</token>.

trans-unit.source: <token>secondref_acs</token> uses rule groups and rules to add, remove or change claims in a token.
trans-unit.target: <token>secondref_acs</token> uses rule groups and rules to add, remove or change claims in a token.

trans-unit.source: For more information read <link xlink:href="7ef0ec98-9fa8-4671-bcf7-630ebb06ec7e" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">Rule Groups and Rules</link>.
trans-unit.target: For more information read <link xlink:href="7ef0ec98-9fa8-4671-bcf7-630ebb06ec7e" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">Rule Groups and Rules</link>.

trans-unit.source: <legacyBold>Encryption</legacyBold>.
trans-unit.target: <legacyBold>Encryption</legacyBold>.

trans-unit.source: Encryption and other cryptographic operations such as signing, signature validation, and decryption directly affect performance.
trans-unit.target: Encryption and other cryptographic operations such as signing, signature validation, and decryption directly affect performance.

trans-unit.source: Cryptography operations consume computation power due to the complex algorithms involved.
trans-unit.target: Cryptography operations consume computation power due to the complex algorithms involved.

trans-unit.source: ACS signs all tokens issued as an integrity measure to counter tampering attacks.
trans-unit.target: ACS signs all tokens issued as an integrity measure to counter tampering attacks.

trans-unit.source: Signature validation of tokens is not optional.
trans-unit.target: Signature validation of tokens is not optional.

trans-unit.source: Token encryption is required if a relying party application is a web service that is not using SSL to encrypt communications.
trans-unit.target: Token encryption is required if a relying party application is a web service that is not using SSL to encrypt communications.

trans-unit.source: WCF-based services using SOAP require encrypted, proof-of-possession tokens with the WS-Trust protocol.
trans-unit.target: WCF-based services using SOAP require encrypted, proof-of-possession tokens with the WS-Trust protocol.

trans-unit.source: Token encryption is required to protect sensitive information over an unencrypted channel.
trans-unit.target: Token encryption is required to protect sensitive information over an unencrypted channel.

trans-unit.source: However, in cases where the communication channel is encrypted, such as using SSL encryption, then using token encryption is optional and may not be applied in favor of improved performance.
trans-unit.target: However, in cases where the communication channel is encrypted, such as using SSL encryption, then using token encryption is optional and may not be applied in favor of improved performance.
